page.title: 01RUTLAND
page.content: In 1974 Rutland finally lost the battle to retain its status as the ssmallest county in England, however there is still 'much in little'. The history of the area is full of links with Royalty as Rutland was traditionally part of the dower of the queens of England. Edward the Confessor bequeathed it to Queen Edith whose name survives to this day at Edith Weston. In Rutland one finds many of the attractive features of the surrounding countryside which varies from the broad valley of the River Welland to the compact hills of eastern Leicester shire. In addition to the market towns of Oakham and Uppingham, each with its well_known independent school, there are 50 villages scattered throughout the unspoilt countryside.
